page.title: Occupy movement in the United States

rev.diff:
Line 49: Line 49:
==Higher Education==
==Higher Education==
Occupy movements have taking place on college campuses across the United States. [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]] <ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/10/occupy-uc-berkeley-police_n_1086195.html]</ref>, [[San Francisco State University]], [[University of California, Irvine|UC Irvine]]<ref name="Occupy Takes Over UCI>["http://www.newuniversity.org/2011/11/news/23976/] 8 November 2011. Retrieved 10 November 2011. </ref>, and [[Harvard University]]<ref name= "Occupy Harvard">[http://www.bostonherald.com/news/regional/view/20111110occupy_harvard_students_pitch_tents_in_harvard_yard/srvc=home&position=recent]</ref> are some institutions of higher education that have held occupations in support of the Occupy movement. Students at [[Saint Mary's College of California]] held teach-ins to educate students on the Occupy movement and encourage them to get involved.<ref name="Occupy SMC">[http://www.contracostatimes.com/ci_19256870?IADID=Search-www.contracostatimes.com-www.contracostatimes.com]3 November 2011. Retrieved 10 November 2011.</ref>
Occupy movements have taking place on college campuses across the United States. [[University of California, Berkeley|UC Berkeley]] <ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/11/10/occupy-uc-berkeley-police_n_1086195.html]</ref>, [[San Francisco State University]], [[University of California, Irvine|UC Irvine]]<ref name="Occupy Takes Over UCI>["http://www.newuniversity.org/2011/11/news/23976/] 8 November 2011. Retrieved 10 November 2011. </ref>, and [[Harvard University]]<ref name= "Occupy Harvard">[http://www.bostonherald.com/news/regional/view/20111110occupy_harvard_students_pitch_tents_in_harvard_yard/srvc=home&position=recent]</ref> are some institutions of higher education that have held occupations in support of the Occupy movement. Students at [[Saint Mary's College of California]] held teach-ins to educate students on the Occupy movement and encourage them to get involved.<ref name="Occupy SMC">[http://www.contracostatimes.com/ci_19256870?IADID=Search-www.contracostatimes.com-www.contracostatimes.com]3 November 2011. Retrieved 10 November 2011.</ref>
  +   +
==Public Opinion==
  +
An October 12â16 poll found that 67% of New York City voters agreed with the protesters and 87% believed that they had a right to protest.<ref name="reuters17thpoll">Reuters (October 17, 2011) [http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/17/us-protests-idUSTRE79G55O20111017 "New Yorkers support anti-Wall Street protests: poll"] ''Reuters.com''</ref> A [[Public Policy Polling]] released on November 16 shows 45% of Americans opposing the movement and 33% favoring it. <ref>http://dailycaller.com/2011/11/16/poll-45-percent-oppose-the-99-percent/ Dail Caller 45 percent oppose the 99 percent</ref> A national [[Wall Street Journal]] poll asked Americans whether they consider themselves supporters of the Occupy Wall Street movement. 28% say they do; 63% say they do not. <ref>http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970203914304576627541092443886.html NBC/WSJ November poll</ref> A Siena poll of New York released on November 15 shows that two-thirds of New Yorkers do not believe that the movement represents "the 99%". <ref> http://blogs.buffalonews.com/politics_now/2011/11/siena-poll-good-news-for-obama-occupy-campers.html Buffalo News Siena Poll Good News for Obama and Occupy Campers</ref>
